title: 106_s2569
content: SECTION 1. HUBZONE SMALL BUSINESS CONCERN. Section 3(p)(3) of the Small Business Act is amended to define a HUBZone small business concern as a small business owned and controlled by U.S. citizens, or an Alaska Native Corporation owned by Natives, or a subsidiary corporation, joint venture, or partnership of an Alaska Native Corporation. The text chunk discusses the eligibility criteria for a small business concern to qualify as a HUBZone small business. It includes ownership and control requirements related to Alaska Native Corporations and Indian tribal governments. Indian tribal governments, or a corporation wholly owned by Indian tribal governments, must have all other owners as either United States citizens or small business concerns. SEC. 2. QUALIFIED HUBZONE SMALL BUSINESS CONCERN. The Small Business Act is amended to define a HUBZone small business concern as one with its principal office located in a HUBZone and at least 35% of its employees residing in a HUBZone. The Small Business Act requires a HUBZone small business concern to have at least 35% of its employees residing in a HUBZone or an Indian reservation governed by tribal government owners. The small business concern must attempt to maintain this employment percentage. The Small Business Act requires a HUBZone small business concern to have at least 35% of its employees residing in a HUBZone or an Indian reservation governed by tribal government owners. A new HUBZone pilot program for sparsely populated areas is introduced, allowing flexibility in employment requirements from 2000 to 2003. On September 30, 2003, a small business concern in Alaska, an Alaska Native Corporation, or a subsidiary, joint venture, or partnership can qualify as a HUBZone small business if its principal office is in a HUBZone within the state and at least 35% of its employees working on awarded contracts are in the HUBZone. The contract awarded under section 31(b) requires the work to be performed in a HUBZone within the State of Alaska, with at least 35% of employees residing in a HUBZone in Alaska or an Alaska Native Village. This requirement does not apply in subsequent fiscal years if the total contract dollars awarded exceed a certain threshold. The contract dollars awarded in support of contracting goals for small businesses in Alaska must be more than 2% of the total contract dollars awarded nationally to small businesses. This does not disqualify a HUBZone small business from performing a contract awarded to it. The Small Business Act allows a HUBZone small business to perform a contract awarded to it based on a preference provided under section 31(b). Section 3(p)(5)(D)(i) is amended to clarify the certification required for a qualified HUBZone small business concern. Section 3(p)(5)(D)(i) is amended to clarify the certification required for a qualified HUBZone small business concern. SEC. 3. OTHER DEFINITIONS. Section 3(p) of the Small Business Act is amended to include definitions related to Native American small business concerns, such as Alaska Native Corporation, Alaska Native Village, and Indian reservation. The term "Indian country" in section 1151 of title 18, United States Code excludes lands within a State where a tribe lacked governmental jurisdiction on the date of enactment, unless recognized later by Congress or the Secretary of the Interior. Indian group exists as an Indian tribe according to the Code of Federal Regulations, including lands taken into trust or acquired by an Indian tribe after the enactment date, not located within or contiguous to Indian reservations. In Oklahoma, it refers to lands within jurisdictional boundaries. In Oklahoma, it refers to lands within jurisdictional boundaries recognized by the Secretary of the Interior as eligible for trust land status under part 151 of title 25, Code of Federal Regulations.
